Nothing new has been revealed to the terrorists. No information has been revealed that would harm national security. If a terrorist doesn't know that his communications are being monitored, then that person is incapable of tying his shoes or successfully carrying out any destructive activities.

Why didn’t the NSA thwart the Boston attack? Common sense says that looking for a needle in a haystack and piling on more and more hay is counterproductive.

In the run-up to 9/11, the Bush administration was repeatedly warned by top CIA officials about the danger that Bin Laden posed, suspicious activity at a flight school should have raised red flags, and the warning of the August 6, 2001 presidential daily brief, "Bin Laden Determined to Strike in U.S." was ignored. They failed to “connect the dots.”

The NSA has been trying to take credit for thwarting two terrorists plots involving Najibullah Zazi and David Headley. But the evidence in these cases shows that traditional investigative work, old-fashioned tips, and conventional surveillance techniques led to the investigations.

NSA Surveillance Played Little Role in Foiling Terror Plots, Experts Say

This is a wonderful essay. My grandmother had Alzheimer's also. My mother cared for her in our home. I was newly married and living in NYC during this time. When I saw how stressful it was for my mom to care for her, I told my husband I was moving back home to help. He was in med school and moved back to NJ with me.  I was very pregnant with my first child at the time and I was the only one who could get her into the shower. She was so terrified of the shower that I had to strip my clothes off and get into the shower with her. It is a funny/sad memory. I now have 3 grown daughters who all helped when my mother in law died of lung cancer 10 years ago. I was never so proud of them ..... They would bathe her, hold her , feed her . It made me realize that they were watching me throughout the years, caring for my parents and various nieces and nephews.  I learned from my mother and they learned from me.  Children may not do what you say, but they are watching you and will do what they see you do. The way to teach them is through example.

I was so pleased with the Cantabridgian Prince's name! We have George, to remind us that the current Royal Family are all descended from "the Elector of Hanover" (meaning, English was the second language of many Kings of England who used the name George ... if they spoke it at all). We have Alexander, to remind us of the close familial ties between Her Majesty's grandfather and the Russian Imperial House of Holstein-Gottorp-Romanov. And then we have Louis, bringing the Battenberg family back into the picture along with the House of "Saxe-Coburg and Gotha". That last House is somehow related to the House of Schleswig-Holstein, although my head swims at trying to make even the few connections I've already made!

The proud great-grandmother, Her Majesty the Queen, has surpassed George III and now is only 2 years, 7 weeks shy of Queen Victoria's record for longest reign by a British sovereign! But I didn't realize that "Victoria" was not her first name. Even as I hope the current monarch remains in service, happy and glorious, for many years, I hope the Prince of Wales chooses a different name should he accede to the throne. Kings named Charles presided over rather tempestuous times; besides, they already have a dog breed named for them.

It's probably too much to hope that he might use his third name (of 4).

I think you're right, there is something special about that first era of pop and rock stars from the 60s. As gemli said, they created a new sound, which was irresistible. Whoever wrote the phrase 'the soundtrack of our lives' nailed it. The music, especially the early material of that time, is enduring. Why? Is it because its energy, its indescribable feeling, captured the energy of an electrified time in history? It can't be a coincidence that this music emerged at the same time as some of the most wrenching, critical social changes in history. I was a teen in the 70s, and no one wanted to talk about the 60s then-- hippies had become a joke and everything sucked. But with every passing year, I appreciate more and more what a time of incredible transformation the 60s were and I'm glad I was alive to know and feel that change in the air, even if I was just a child.

I recently discovered the show Freaks and Geeks, which uses original soundtracks from older rock songs. One episode exclusively used Who songs, and it was as if I had never heard them before. By the time the opening chords of "Going Mobile" started, I had tears in my eyes. I don't know why! But I was so moved!

They want elected officials chosen by their more engaged neighbors who will do their job so they can go on and live their lives with out being bothered.

"When you're born ,,, you are put on the register of citizens automatically." Of course, that's true in America, too. That *is* what a birth certificate does, right? The problem here is that you have to keep registering -- for Social Security (working), for school, for medical care, for driving, for travel (passport), for voting, etc. And, more and more often, you have to show one or more prior registrations for the next one.

There is a strong resistance to the idea of a universal identification registration in America, but I can't help thinking maybe it's what we need.

It used to be that we could brag about our democracy when we travel abroad. But, recently visiting in Europe, I told a friend that I was involved in registering voters. He was shocked. "Here," he said, "when you're born or when you become a citizen, you are put on the register of citizens automatically (and also signed up for the country's universal health care system, by the way)."

We could do that. Then there'd be no problem of voter fraud, arguments over how long before the election you have to register. It is the country's obligation to enable every citizen to exercise his or her right to vote.

Meanwhile, in rural areas in the American South where people who don't drive need to go hundreds of miles to get the proper ID, the right to vote becomes super-hard to exercise.
